|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203032139/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2012/04/vigil_today_for_gina_dejesus_m.html |archivedate=December 3, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Captivity== After Knight's kidnapping, Castro took her upstairs, tied her hands and feet together, and pulled her up using her hands, feet, and neck. He left her there for three days without food. Prosecutors at Castro's sentencing wrote that diaries kept by the women "speak of forced sexual conduct, of being locked in a dark room, of anticipating the next session of abuse, of the dreams of someday escaping and being reunited with family, of being chained to a wall, of being held like a [[prisoner of war]], of missing the lives they once enjoyed, of [[Psychological abuse|emotional abuse]], of his threats to kill, of being treated like an animal, of continuous abuse, and of desiring freedom". The women were kept in locked upstairs bedrooms, where they were forced to use plastic toilets that were "emptied infrequently".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/07/ariel_castro_sentencing_memo_r.html |title=Ariel Castro sentencing memorandum filed by prosecutors |last1=Krouse |first1=Peter |date=July 31, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=August 6, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130804045034/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/07/ariel_castro_sentencing_memo_r.html |archivedate=August 4, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> They were fed one meal a day, and allowed to shower twice a week at most.<ref name=cnn080213>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/08/01/justice/ohio-cleveland-castro-home |title=Deception, threats and abuse: Captives' hellish life inside Castro's home |last1=Botelho |first1=Greg |date=August 2, 2013 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=August 6, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130805195802/http://www.cnn.com/2013/08/01/justice/ohio-cleveland-castro-home |archivedate=August 5, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Knight told police that Castro had impregnated her at least five times, and had induced [[miscarriage]]s each time through beatings: hitting with [[dumbbell]]s, punching, and slamming her against walls. Starvation was also included.<ref name=trib/><ref name=cbs>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57583620/michelle-knight-told-cops-ariel-castro-threatened-to-kill-her-if-amanda-berrys-baby-died/ |title=Michelle Knight told cops Ariel Castro threatened to kill her if Amanda Berry's baby died |date=May 9, 2013 |publisher=CBS News |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130513001627/http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57583620/michelle-knight-told-cops-ariel-castro-threatened-to-kill-her-if-amanda-berrys-baby-died/ |archivedate=May 13, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Knight's grandmother told reporters that she would require [[Oral and maxillofacial surgery|facial reconstruction]] surgery due to the beatings she endured; she also lost hearing in one ear.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57583875/michelle-knight-needs-facial-reconstruction-after-cleveland-rescue-grandmother-says/ |title=Michelle Knight needs "facial reconstruction" after Cleveland rescue, grandmother says |date=May 10, 2013 |publisher=CBS News |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk6I10LA?url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57583875/michelle-knight-needs-facial-reconstruction-after-cleveland-rescue-grandmother-says/ |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> At one point, Knight had a pet dog while in captivity, but Castro killed the dog by snapping its neck after it bit him while trying to protect Knight.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/05/michelle-knight-dr-phil_n_4221776.html|title=Ariel Castro Used Barbell To Force Miscarriage: Michelle Knight|work=The Huffington Post|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109060020/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/05/michelle-knight-dr-phil_n_4221776.html|archivedate=November 9, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> DeJesus told law enforcement she was raped but did not believe she was ever impregnated.<ref name=cbs />
In December 2006, Castro allegedly ordered Knight to assist in the birth of Berry's child, which took place in a small inflatable swimming pool, and threatened to kill Knight if the baby did not survive. At one point, the baby stopped breathing, but Knight was able to resuscitate her.<ref name=clbaby>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/authorities_say_daughter_of_am.html |title=Authorities say daughter of Amanda Berry born in inflatable pool |last1=Caniglia |first1=John |date=May 8, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510122911/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/authorities_say_daughter_of_am.html |archivedate=May 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/police_report_michelle_knight.html |title=Police report: Michelle Knight revived Amanda Berry's baby just after birth |last1=Blackwell |first1=Brandon |date=May 9, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510100442/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/police_report_michelle_knight.html |archivedate=May 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Castro occasionally took the child out of the house, including to visit his mother; the girl called Castro "daddy" and Castro's mother "grandmother".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/08/ohio-missing-berry-dejesus-knight-castro/2143919/ |title=Latest revelations in Ohio captivity case |last1=Webb |first1=Robin |date=May 8, 2013 |newspaper=USA Today |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512220227/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/08/ohio-missing-berry-dejesus-knight-castro/2143919/ |archivedate=May 12, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/30_minutes_that_ended_a_decade.html |title=The rescue of Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus and Michelle Knight: 30 minutes that ended a decade of nightmares |last1=Gomez |first1=Henry J. |date=May 13, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk6Uwrmv?url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/30_minutes_that_ended_a_decade.html |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In 2013, he showed one of his adult daughters a picture of the child and said that she was his girlfriend's daughter from another man. He had told others who saw her that she was his granddaughter.<ref name=clbaby/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/05/09/us/ohio-suspect-daughter/ |title='He is dead to me,' daughter of Ohio suspect says in CNN exclusive |last1=Segall |first1=Laura |last2=Fink |first2=Erica |last3=Brumfield |first3=Ben |date=May 10, 2013 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512205909/http://www.cnn.com/2013/05/09/us/ohio-suspect-daughter |archivedate=May 12, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
According to a statement from Cleveland Police, officers visited Castro's home only once following the kidnappings to discuss an unrelated incident. Castro did not appear to be home at the time and was later interviewed elsewhere. Although neighbors claimed to have called the police about suspicious activity observed at the home, police have said they have no record of any such calls.<ref name="Police deny neighbors called about suspicious activity">{{cite web |author=Levs, Josh |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/05/08/justice/ohio-police-investigation/index.html |title=Police deny neighbors called about suspicious activity at Castro home |date=May 8, 2013 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510040233/http://www.cnn.com/2013/05/08/justice/ohio-police-investigation/index.html |archivedate=May 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} Also published by WHNT as "[http://whnt.com/2013/05/08/ariel-castro-charged-with-kidnapping-rape-brothers-pedro-and-onil-released/ Ariel Castro Charged with Kidnapping, Rape; Brothers Pedro and Onil Released] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510155443/http://whnt.com/2013/05/08/ariel-castro-charged-with-kidnapping-rape-brothers-pedro-and-onil-released/ |date=May 10, 2013 }}".</ref> Castro's son Anthony reported that there were certain areas of the house that were inaccessible due to being locked.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/homeowner-where-3-women-were-found-was-no-stranger |title=In Ohio neighborhood, suspect was familiar figure |last1=Washington |first1=Jesse |date=May 7, 2013 |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130625072717/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/homeowner-where-3-women-were-found-was-no-stranger |archivedate=June 25, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} Also published by NewsNet5.com (WEWS-TV) as "[http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/family-friend-kidnapping-suspect-ariel-castro-was-friends-with-gina-dejesus-father-helped-search Family friend: Kidnapping suspect Ariel Castro was friends with Gina DeJesus' father, helped search] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510004908/http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/family-friend-kidnapping-suspect-ariel-castro-was-friends-with-gina-dejesus-father-helped-search |date=May 10, 2013 }}"</ref> He also mentioned an occasion where, three weeks before the women's escape, Castro asked him if Berry would ever be found. Anthony said he told Castro that Berry was likely dead, to which Castro responded: "Really? You think so?"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/kidnap-suspect-bizarre-question-son-article-1.1337753 |title=Main Cleveland kidnapping suspect's son says dad recently asked him whether one of the victims would be found |last1=Hutchinson |first1=Bill |date=May 7, 2013 |newspaper=New York Daily News |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130509234228/http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/kidnap-suspect-bizarre-question-son-article-1.1337753 |archivedate=May 9, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
[[NBC]] affiliate [[WKYC]] reported that during Castro's interrogation, he recalled each of the three abductions in great detail and indicated that they were unplanned [[Crime of opportunity|crimes of opportunity]]. According to WKYC's sources, Castro did not have an "exit plan" and believed that he would eventually be caught. He referred to himself as "coldblooded" and a [[Sexual addiction|sex addict]].<ref name="USA Today 20130510">{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/10/ariel-castro-cleveland-abduction-cold-blood-kidnap/2149831/ |title=Ariel Castro to cops: 'I'm coldblooded' |last1=Meyer |first1=Tom |date=May 10, 2013 |newspaper=USA Today |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512231813/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/10/ariel-castro-cleveland-abduction-cold-blood-kidnap/2149831/ |archivedate=May 12, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wkyc.com/video/default.aspx?bctid=2369153756001 |title=Investigator: Inside Ariel Castro's interrogation |publisher=WKYC |accessdate=September 4, 2013}}</ref> Police found a [[suicide note]] in Castro's home in which he allegedly discussed the abductions and wrote that his money, videos and possessions should be given to the kidnapped women if he were caught.<ref name="USA Today 20130510"/>
==Escape and rescue== On May 6, 2013, Berry was finally able to make contact with Castro's neighbors, leading to her escape with her 6-year-old daughter,<!-- Again, do not add the daughter's name, see talk page. --> and the rescue of DeJesus and Knight by authorities.<ref name= newsnet5-found/> According to police, when Castro left the house that day, Berry realized that he failed to lock the home's "big inside door", although the exterior storm door was bolted.<ref name="BBC Cleveland rescue">{{cite web|title=Cleveland rescue: The mystery of 2207 Seymour Avenue|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22446157|accessdate=May 14, 2013|publisher=BBC|date=May 10, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510102101/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22446157|archivedate=May 10, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=McClam|first=Erin|title=Cleveland man charged with kidnapping, rape; no charges for 2 brothers|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/05/08/18123601-cleveland-man-charged-with-kidnapping-rape-no-charges-for-2-brothers?lite|accessdate=May 13, 2013|publisher=NBC News|date=May 9, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130513185729/http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/05/08/18123601-cleveland-man-charged-with-kidnapping-rape-no-charges-for-2-brothers?lite|archivedate=May 13, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Martinez|first=Michael|title=As Ohio women remained in captivity, alleged abductor's life crumbled|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/05/12/us/cleveland-abductions-narrative/index.html|accessdate=May 14, 2013|publisher=CNN|date=May 13, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130513104357/http://www.cnn.com/2013/05/12/us/cleveland-abductions-narrative/index.html|archivedate=May 13, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Alcindor|first1=Yamiche|title=Ariel Castro charged with kidnapping, rape of 3 Cleveland women|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/08/cleveland-kidnap-captured-chains-ropes/2143885/|accessdate=May 14, 2013|newspaper=USA Today|date=May 9, 2013|last2=Leger|first2=Donna Leinwand|last3=Strauss|first3=Gary|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130513160304/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/08/cleveland-kidnap-captured-chains-ropes/2143885/|archivedate=May 13, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> She did not attempt to break through the outer door because "she thought [Castro] was testing her", according to the police report. Previously, Castro tested the women by leaving the house partially unlocked and exits unsecured. If they attempted to escape, he beat them. Instead, Berry screamed for help when she saw neighbors through the screen.<ref name="BBC Cleveland rescue"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Mahoney|first=Jill|title=Death penalty possible for alleged Cleveland kidnapper, prosecutor says |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/kidnap-suspect-ariel-castro-due-in-cleveland-court/article11810618/|accessdate=May 14, 2013|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|date=May 10, 2013|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130615115016/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/kidnap-suspect-ariel-castro-due-in-cleveland-court/article11810618/|archivedate=June 15, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Dolan|first1=Matthew|title=Charges Filed in Abduction of Ohio Women|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324059704578470750534634028|accessdate=May 14, 2013|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=May 9, 2013|last2=Barrett|first2=Joe|last3=El-Ghobashy|first3=Tamer|last4=Maher|first4=Kris|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151015195936/http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324059704578470750534634028|archivedate=October 15, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Meyer |first=Tom |title=Investigator: Amanda Berry delivered baby in plastic pool |url=http://www.wkyc.com/news/article/298772/45/Investigator-Read-details-of-captives-lives-escape |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130615114910/http://www.wkyc.com/news/article/298772/45/Investigator-Read-details-of-captives-lives-escape |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 15, 2013 |accessdate=May 14, 2013 |publisher=WKYC |date=May 9, 2013 }}</ref>
Neighbor Angel Cordero responded to the screaming<ref name="slates">{{cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2013/05/08/_angel_cordero_cleveland_kidnapping_nobody_s_praising_the_less_flamboyant.html |title=Nobody's Praising Angel Cordero, the Less-Flamboyant Neighbor Who Also Helped Free Amanda Berry |last1=Levin |first1=Josh |date=May 8, 2013 |publisher=Slate |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk6Y2tgc?url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2013/05/08/_angel_cordero_cleveland_kidnapping_nobody_s_praising_the_less_flamboyant.html |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> but was unable to communicate with Berry, because he spoke little English. Another neighbor, Charles Ramsey, joined Cordero at the house's front door during the rescue.<ref>{{cite web|title=Charles Ramsey interview, rescuer of Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus and Michelle Knight in Cleveland|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=axCn04iXkBg|website=YouTube|publisher=News 5 Cleveland|accessdate=January 26, 2018|date=May 6, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180221202653/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=axCn04iXkBg|archivedate=February 21, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref> A hole was kicked through the bottom of the storm door, and Berry crawled through, carrying her daughter; Ramsey said Berry told him that she and her child were being kept inside the house against her will. Upon being freed, she went to the house of another Spanish-speaking neighbor<ref name="slates"/> and called [[9-1-1]], saying;
{{Reduced pull quote|1=center|width=92%|2=Help me, I've been kidnapped, and I've been missing for ten years. And I'm here. I'm free now!|3=Amanda Berry|4=call to 911.<ref name=cnn050713/><ref name="autogenerated8">{{cite web |url=http://cnnpressroom.blogs.cnn.com/2013/05/07/transcript-video-charles-ramsey-ac360-exclusive-invu/ |title=Anderson Cooper interview with Charles Ramsey |date=May 7, 2013 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=May 8, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130608160414/http://cnnpressroom.blogs.cnn.com/2013/05/07/transcript-video-charles-ramsey-ac360-exclusive-invu/ |archivedate=June 8, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>}}
Responding police officers entered Castro's house. As they walked through an upstairs hallway with guns drawn, they announced themselves as Cleveland Police. After peeking out from a slightly opened bedroom door, Knight entered the hallway and leaped into an officer's arms, repeatedly saying, "You saved me." Soon afterward, DeJesus entered the hallway from another room.<ref name="cleveland1"/> Knight and DeJesus walked out of the home, and all three women, plus the child, were taken to [[MetroHealth|MetroHealth Medical Center]].<ref name="3 missing women found"/> Berry and DeJesus were released from the hospital the next day.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/08/cleveland-kidnap-michelle-knight-amanda-berry/2144153/ |title=2 freed women return home; 3rd still in hospital |last1=Alcindor |first1=Yamiche |last2=Bacon |first2=John |date=May 8, 2013 |newspaper=USA Today |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130509064633/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/08/cleveland-kidnap-michelle-knight-amanda-berry/2144153/ |archivedate=May 9, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Knight was discharged four days later, on May 10.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/cleveland-captive-knight-avoids-public-family-article-1.1341364 |title=Cleveland captive Michelle Knight leaves hospital without telling family |last1=Walsh |first1=Michael |date=May 11, 2013 |newspaper=New York Daily News |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130602124538/http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/cleveland-captive-knight-avoids-public-family-article-1.1341364 |archivedate=June 2, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Arrest and legal proceedings== [[File:Ariel Castro FBI interrogation.png|thumbnail|right|Screenshot showing Castro's interrogation by the FBI]] Castro was arrested on May 6, 2013.<ref name="plain-dealer-charges"/> He was charged with four counts of kidnapping and three counts of rape on May 8, which carry [[prison sentence]]s of ten years to life in Ohio.<ref name="plain-dealer-charges"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://codes.ohio.gov/orc/2971.03 |title=2971.03 Sentencing for sexually violent predator specification |publisher=LAWriter – ORC |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130513054559/http://codes.ohio.gov/orc/2971.03 |archivedate=May 13, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Two of Castro's brothers were also initially taken into custody, but were released on May 9 after police announced that they had no involvement in the kidnappings.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ohio-suspects-brothers-released-custody |title=Ohio suspect's brothers released from custody |date=May 9, 2013 |publisher=Yahoo! |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130609021837/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ohio-suspects-brothers-released-custody |archivedate=June 9, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Castro made his first court appearance at the Cleveland [[Ohio Municipal Courts|Municipal Court]] on May 9, where [[bail]] was set at $2 million per kidnapping charge, adding to a total of $8 million.<ref name="LA Times bail">{{cite news|last=Muskal|first=Michael|title=Ariel Castro's bail set at $8 million in Cleveland abduction case|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ariel-castro-bail-set-cleveland-20130509,0,6364727.story|accessdate=May 15, 2013|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=May 9, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516120848/http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ariel-castro-bail-set-cleveland-20130509,0,6364727.story|archivedate=May 16, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="Washington Post man accused">{{cite news|last=Markon|first=Jerry|title=Cleveland man accused of kidnapping, raping 3 women held on $8 million bond|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/man-accused-of-kidnapping-raping-3-women-held-on-8-million-bond/2013/05/09/3a7656b0-b8e7-11e2-92f3-f291801936b8_story.html|accessdate=May 15, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=May 9, 2013|last2=Wilgoren|first2=Debbi|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512141934/http://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/man-accused-of-kidnapping-raping-3-women-held-on-8-million-bond/2013/05/09/3a7656b0-b8e7-11e2-92f3-f291801936b8_story.html|archivedate=May 12, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/09/cleveland-ariel-castro-amanda-berry-arraignment-kidnap-rape/2146289/ |title=Prosecutor: Ariel Castro could face death penalty |last1=Leger |first1=Donna Leinwand |last2=Strauss |first2=Gary |date=May 10, 2013 |newspaper=USA Today |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511091619/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/09/cleveland-ariel-castro-amanda-berry-arraignment-kidnap-rape/2146289/ |archivedate=May 11, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Additional charges were reported to be pending, including [[Aggravation (law)|aggravated murder]] (for intentional induction of miscarriages), [[attempted murder]], [[assault]], a charge for each alleged instance of rape, and a kidnapping charge for each day each captive was allegedly held.<ref name="pd090513"/> On May 14, Castro's attorneys said he would plead "not guilty" to all charges if indicted for kidnapping and rape.<ref name="WKYC Investigator">{{cite news|last=Meyer |first=Tom |title=Investigator: Castro loves daughter, will plead 'not guilty' |url=http://www.wkyc.com/news/article/299605/45/Investigator-Castro-loves-daughter-will-plead-not-guilty |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130615114847/http://www.wkyc.com/news/article/299605/45/Investigator-Castro-loves-daughter-will-plead-not-guilty |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 15, 2013 |accessdate=May 14, 2013 |publisher=WKYC |date=May 14, 2013 }}</ref><ref name="BBC to plead innocent">{{cite news|title=Cleveland kidnap accused Castro to plead innocent – lawyers|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22543247|accessdate=May 15, 2012|publisher=BBC|date=May 15, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516014858/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22543247|archivedate=May 16, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="Reuters to plead not guilty">{{cite news|author=Palmer, Kim|title=Accused Cleveland kidnapper plans to plead not guilty: lawyer|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/15/us-usa-missing-ohio-idUSBRE94E0LT20130515|accessdate=May 15, 2013|agency=Reuters|date=May 15, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515220240/http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/15/us-usa-missing-ohio-idUSBRE94E0LT20130515|archivedate=May 15, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
A [[Cuyahoga County, Ohio|Cuyahoga County]] [[grand jury]] returned a [[Indictment|true bill]] of indictment against Castro on June 7. It contained 329 counts, including two counts of aggravated murder (under different sections of the Ohio criminal code) for his alleged role in the termination of one of the women's pregnancies. The indictments covered only the period from August 2002 to February 2007. The county prosecutor, Timothy J. McGinty, stated that the investigation was ongoing, and that any further findings would be presented to the grand jury. McGinty said that pursuing a [[death penalty]] specification would be considered following completion of indictment proceedings.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/06/ariel_castro_indicted_on_charg.html |title=Ariel Castro indicted on aggravated murder, rape, kidnapping charges |last=McCarty |first=James F. |date=June 7, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=September 4, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130907111035/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/06/ariel_castro_indicted_on_charg.html |archivedate=September 7, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Ohio grand jury indicts man accused of kidnapping Cleveland women |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/08/us-usa-missing-ohio-idUSBRE95619F20130608?feedType=RSS&feedName=topNews&dlvrit=992637 |last1=Palmer |first=Kim |date=June 8, 2013 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=June 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130608025533/http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/08/us-usa-missing-ohio-idUSBRE95619F20130608?feedType=RSS |archivedate=June 8, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
After entering a not guilty plea for Castro on June 12, one of his attorneys, Craig Weintraub, said that although some of the charges against Castro were indisputable, "it is our hope that we can continue to work toward a resolution to avoid having an unnecessary trial about aggravated murder and the death penalty". He noted, "We are very sensitive to the emotional strain and impact that a trial would have on the women, their families and this community".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ariel-castro-plea-20130612,0,6763994.story |title=Ariel Castro's lawyer: Some kidnap charges 'cannot be disputed' |last=Pearce |first=Matt |date=June 12, 2013 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=June 19, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615022557/http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ariel-castro-plea-20130612,0,6763994.story |archivedate=June 15, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Castro was found competent to stand trial on July 3.<ref>{{cite news |title=Accused Cleveland kidnapper ruled capable of standing trial |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/03/justice/ohio-castro-hearing/index.html |date=July 3, 2013 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=September 4, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130907063712/http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/03/justice/ohio-castro-hearing/index.html |archivedate=September 7, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On July 12, a Cuyahoga County grand jury returned a true bill of indictment for the remainder of the period after February 2007. It brought the total to 977 counts: 512 counts of kidnapping, 446 of rape, seven of gross sexual imposition, six of felonious assault, three of [[child endangerment]], two of aggravated murder, and one of possession of criminal tools.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/12/justice/ohio-castro-indictment/index.html?hpt=hp_t2 |title=Cleveland kidnapping suspect now faces 977 counts |date=July 13, 2013 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=July 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130713162930/http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/12/justice/ohio-castro-indictment/index.html?hpt=hp_t2 |archivedate=July 13, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> On July 17, Castro pleaded not guilty to the expanded indictment.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sheeran|first=Thomas J.|title=Ohio kidnapping, rape suspect pleads not guilty|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/2nd-arraignment-set-ohio-kidnap-suspect|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=October 4, 2013|date=July 17, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20131004225023/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/2nd-arraignment-set-ohio-kidnap-suspect|archivedate=October 4, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Castro pleaded guilty on July 26 to 937 of the 977 charges against him, including charges of kidnapping, rape, and aggravated murder, as part of a [[plea bargain]] which called for consecutive sentences of [[life imprisonment|life in prison]] plus 1,000 years, all without [[parole]].<ref name=usat072613/> Under the plea deal, Castro forfeited his right to [[appeal]], and could not profit in any way due to his crimes. He also forfeited his assets, including his home, which prosecutors said would be demolished.<ref name=cl072613>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/07/ariel_castro_agrees_to_plea_de.html |title=Ariel Castro agrees to plea deal: Life in prison, no parole, plus 1,000 years for abduction, rapes of Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus and Michelle Knight |last1=Krouse |first1=Peter |date=July 26, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=July 26, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130730041818/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/07/ariel_castro_agrees_to_plea_de.html |archivedate=July 30, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Castro was told by Cuyahoga County [[Ohio Courts of Common Pleas|Common Pleas Court]] Judge Michael Russo, "You will not be getting out. Is that clear?" to which Castro responded, "I do understand that, your honor."<ref name="BBC-plea">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-23468222 |title=Ariel Castro to serve life in prison under plea deal |publisher=BBC News |date=July 26, 2013 |accessdate=July 26, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130727013327/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-23468222 |archivedate=July 27, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Castro also made comments about his "addiction to [[pornography]]" and "sexual problem", but was cut off by Judge Russo, who said such issues could be discussed at the August 1 sentencing hearing.<ref name=cl072613/> A law firm representing Berry, DeJesus, and Knight released a statement that the three women were "relieved by today's plea. They are satisfied by this resolution to the case, and are looking forward to having these legal proceedings draw to a final close in the near future".<ref name=cl072613/>
At the sentencing hearing on August 1, Castro was sentenced to consecutive life terms in prison, plus 1,000 years, all without any possibility of parole. He was also fined $100,000. The court forfeited all of his property and assets to the Cuyahoga County government.<ref name=pd130801>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/08/judge_sends_ariel_castro_to_pr.html |title=Judge sends Ariel Castro to prison for abduction, rape of Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus and Michelle Knight (slideshow) |date=August 1, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=August 6, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130804045059/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/08/judge_sends_ariel_castro_to_pr.html |archivedate=August 4, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Before his sentencing, Castro addressed the court for twenty minutes, in which he said he was "a good person" and "not a monster", but that he was addicted to sex and pornography, and had "practiced the art of [[masturbation]]" from a young age. He claimed that he had never beaten or tortured the women, and insisted that "most" of the sex he had with them "was consensual". He shifted between an apologetic tone and blaming the FBI for failing to catch him, as well as his victims themselves, insisting to the court that when he had sex with them he discovered they were not virgins. He would alternatively shift back into apologetic comments, saying: "I hope they can find in their hearts to forgive me because we had a lot of harmony going on in that home".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wkyc.com/news/article/308810/45/STATEMENT--Read-Ariel-Castros-final-remarks-in-court |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130806234708/http://www.wkyc.com/news/article/308810/45/STATEMENT--Read-Ariel-Castros-final-remarks-in-court |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 6, 2013 |title=Ariel Castro spoke for 20 minutes in court, read what he said here |date=August 1, 2013 |publisher=WKYC |accessdate=August 6, 2013 }}</ref>
The sentencing judge also heard from Knight and family members of Berry and DeJesus. Knight told Castro: "You took eleven years of my life away. I spent eleven years in hell, now your hell is just beginning. I will overcome all that has happened, but you will face hell for eternity. I will live on, you will die a little every day as you think of the eleven years of atrocities that you inflicted on us... I can forgive you, but I will never forget."<ref name=pd130801/>
==Aftermath== ===Survivors=== On July 9, 2013, Knight, Berry, and DeJesus broke their public silence for the first time since their rescue by releasing a video statement thanking the public for their support. An attorney for Berry and DeJesus said the women "still have a strong desire for privacy" and did not wish to speak to the media about their ordeal.<ref name=pd070913>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/07/amanda_berry_gina_dejesus_and_2.html |title=New video: Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus and Michelle Knight, Cleveland's 3 missing women, thank you for your support |last1=Caniglia |first1=John |date=July 9, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=July 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130710092111/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/07/amanda_berry_gina_dejesus_and_2.html |archivedate=July 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/transcript-cleveland-kidnapping-victims-say-thank-for-support |title=TRANSCRIPT: Cleveland kidnapping victims say thank you for support |last1=Steer |first1=Jen |date=July 9, 2013 |publisher=newsnet5.com |accessdate=July 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130711210648/http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/transcript-cleveland-kidnapping-victims-say-thank-for-support |archivedate=July 11, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The Cleveland Courage Fund, a bank account set up to help the women in their transition to independent life, had collected approximately $1.05 million at the time of the video's release.<ref name=pd070913/> Before Berry's disappearance, her grandfather had promised to give her a classic [[Chevrolet Monte Carlo]] from the year Berry was born. He kept the car after her kidnapping, in case she was still found alive. After her rescue, Berry called her grandfather, and asked if he still had the car, which he did,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/amanda-berrys-grandfather-keeps-1986-monte-carlo-he-promised-before-she-went-missing |title=Amanda Berry's grandfather keeps 1986 Monte Carlo he promised before she went missing |last1=Kiesel |first1=Connor |publisher=Newsnet5.com |date=May 13, 2013 |accessdate=July 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130710181505/http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/amanda-berrys-grandfather-keeps-1986-monte-carlo-he-promised-before-she-went-missing |archivedate=July 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> although it was in need of [[automotive restoration|restoration]] from having gone unused. Several automotive shops offered to perform the restoration for free.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wjhl.com/story/22285475/amanda-berry-and-grandfather-reunite |title=Amanda Berry and grandfather reunite |last1=Morabito |first1=Nate |publisher=WJHL |date=April 17, 2013 |accessdate=July 9, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801005123/http://www.wjhl.com/story/22285475/amanda-berry-and-grandfather-reunite|archivedate=August 1, 2013}}</ref>
In an interview with [[People (magazine)|''People'' magazine]] on the first anniversary of her rescue, Knight discussed some of her ordeals as well as her life leading up to her abduction. Since her rescue, she legally changed her first name to Lily,<ref>{{cite news|last=Feran|first=Tom|title=Michelle Knight conquers her fears after 'dangling in the wind'|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2015/03/michelle_knight_1.html|accessdate=March 16, 2015|newspaper=The Plain Dealer|date=March 14, 2015|quote=Knight has changed her own name legally to Lily[...]but she uses her better-known birth name in public appearances.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316233918/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2015/03/michelle_knight_1.html|archivedate=March 16, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and began to get several tattoos as her way of coping with the healing process. Knight also revealed that her son was adopted by his [[foster care|foster parents]] while she was in captivity, and that while she wanted to see him, she does not want to bring him into the ordeal she has had to deal with, and planned to see him after he becomes an adult. Knight planned to open a restaurant, dreamed of getting married — which she did in 2016<ref>{{cite news|title=Michelle Knight, kept in captivity for over 10 years, reveals her marriage on "Dr. Phil"|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/michelle-knight-kept-in-captivity-for-over-10-years-reveals-her-marriage-on-dr-phil/|work=[[CBS News]]|date=April 10, 2018|access-date=April 11, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180411102025/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/michelle-knight-kept-in-captivity-for-over-10-years-reveals-her-marriage-on-dr-phil/|archivedate=April 11, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref> — and adopt children. Knight also planned to reunite with Berry and DeJesus in the future, but began focusing on getting her own life back on track.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/article/michelle-knight-cleveland-kidnapping-book-excerpt|title=Cleveland Kidnapping Victim Michelle Knight Tells Her Story of Torture and Triumph|publisher=People.com|date=May 9, 2014|accessdate=November 9, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108191416/http://www.people.com/article/michelle-knight-cleveland-kidnapping-book-excerpt|archivedate=November 8, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Berry and DeJesus received honorary diplomas from John Marshall High School in 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2015/05/amanda_berry_gina_dejesus_real.html|title=Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus realize high school graduation dream with John Marshall Class of 2015|newspaper=cleveland.com|access-date=January 4, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018015223/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2015/05/amanda_berry_gina_dejesus_real.html|archivedate=October 18, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===House demolition=== [[File:Seymour Avenue - panoramio.jpg|thumbnail|right|The site on Seymour Avenue in 2014.]] As part of the plea bargain, the house where Castro lived, and where he had held the women captive, was demolished on August 7, 2013. Knight was present and handed out yellow balloons, which she said represented missing children, to the gathered crowd. The balloons were released before DeJesus's aunt began the demolition with a swing of a [[crane (machine)|crane]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/cleveland-house-horrors-destroyed-demolition-crews-tear-ariel-castro-home-article-1.1419792 |title=Cleveland house of horrors destroyed — demolition crews tear down Ariel Castro's home |last1=Kemp |first1=Joe |date=August 7, 2013 |newspaper=NY Daily News |accessdate=August 7, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130810195725/http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/cleveland-house-horrors-destroyed-demolition-crews-tear-ariel-castro-home-article-1.1419792 |archivedate=August 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/cleveland-kidnapper-ariel-castros-house-horrors-demolished/story?id=19890927 |title=Cleveland Kidnapper Ariel Castro's 'House of Horrors' Demolished |last1=Ng |first1=Christina |date=August 7, 2013 |publisher=ABC News |accessdate=August 7, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130810182609/http://abcnews.go.com/US/cleveland-kidnapper-ariel-castros-house-horrors-demolished/story?id=19890927 |archivedate=August 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/oh_cuyahoga/michelle-knight-held-captive-for-decade-by-ariel-castro-hands-out-yellow-balloons-on-seymour-avenue |title=Michelle Knight held captive for decade by Ariel Castro hands out yellow balloons on Seymour Avenue |last1=Seitz |first1=Colleen |date=August 7, 2013 |publisher=newsnet5.com |accessdate=August 7, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130810222225/http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/oh_cuyahoga/michelle-knight-held-captive-for-decade-by-ariel-castro-hands-out-yellow-balloons-on-seymour-avenue |archivedate=August 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

in [[Orient, Ohio]].<ref name="AP suicide">{{cite news |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ohio-man-who-held-3-women-captive-found-dead |title=Cleveland man's suicide brings little sympathy performed [[Cardiopulmonary resuscitation|CPR]] on Castro before he was taken to the [[Wexner Medical Center at Ohio State University|Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center]] in [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]], where he was pronounced dead shortly thereafter.<ref name="AP suicide"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Woods|first=Jim|title=Ariel Castro dies in apparent 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
On October 10, 2013, the [[Ohio Department of Rehabilitation and Correction]] released a report that suggested Castro may have died accidentally from auto-[[erotic asphyxiation]] rather than suicide. Gorniak rejected the possibility, standing by her ruling of suicide. The report also said two prison guards had falsified logs documenting their observation of Castro hours before he was found dead.<ref>{{cite web|title=Castro suicide report: Officers falsified reports|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2013/10/10/Ariel-Castro-suicide-report.html|publisher=The Columbus Dispatch|accessdate=October 10, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131010150554/http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2013/10/10/Ariel-Castro-suicide-report.html|archivedate=October 10, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Castro was not on [[suicide watch]] at the time of his death, but had been subject to routine checks every thirty minutes due to his notoriety.<ref name="AP suicide"/>
A consultant's report was released on December 3, and officially concluded that "all available evidence pointed to suicide, including a shrine-like arrangement of family pictures and a Bible in Castro's cell, an increasing tone of frustration in his prison journal and the reality of spending the rest of his life in prison while subject to constant harassment." The [[Ohio State Highway Patrol]] also reviewed the case and reached the same conclusion.<ref name="suiciderpt">{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/12/03/consultants-ariel-castro-death-suicide/3850515/ |title=Consultants: Kidnapper Ariel Castro's death a suicide |last=Welsh-Huggins |first1=Andrew |date=December 3, 2013 |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=USA Today |accessdate=October 3, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206061146/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/12/03/consultants-ariel-castro-death-suicide/3850515/ |archivedate=December 6, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

{{pp-pc1|small=yes}} {{Other uses}} [[File:Saint Augustine by Philippe de Champaigne.jpg|thumb|[[Augustine of Hippo|Saint Augustine of Hippo]] wrote [[Confessions (Augustine)|''Confessions'']], the first Western autobiography ever written, around 400. Portrait by [[Philippe de Champaigne]], 17th century.]] An '''autobiography''' (from the [[Greek language|Greek]], αὐτός-''autos'' self + βίος-''bios'' life + γράφειν-''graphein'' to write) is a self-written account of the life of oneself. The word "autobiography" was first used deprecatingly by [[William Taylor (scholar)|William Taylor]] in 1797 in the [[English language|English]] [[Periodical publication|periodical]] ''The [[Monthly Review (London)|Monthly Review]]'', when he suggested the word as a hybrid, but condemned it as "pedantic". However, its next recorded use was in its present sense, by [[Robert Southey]] in 1809.<ref>[[Oxford English Dictionary]], ''Autobiography''</ref> Despite only being named early in the nineteenth century, first-person autobiographical writing originates in antiquity. Roy Pascal differentiates autobiography from the periodic self-reflective mode of journal or diary writing by noting that "[autobiography] is a review of a life from a particular moment in time, while the diary, however reflective it may be, moves through a series of moments in time".<ref name=Pascal>{{cite book|last = Pascal| first = Roy|title = Design and Truth in Autobiography|publisher = [[Harvard University Press]] | year = 1960 | location = [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]] | pages = | url =| doi =| id = | isbn = }}</ref> Autobiography thus takes stock of the autobiographer's life from the moment of composition. While biographers generally rely on a wide variety of documents and viewpoints, autobiography may be based entirely on the writer's memory. The [[memoir]] form is closely associated with autobiography but it tends, as Pascal claims, to focus less on the self and more on others during the autobiographer's review of his or her life.<ref name=Pascal/>
''See also: [[List of autobiographies]] and [[:Category:Autobiographies]] for examples.''
== Biography == === Life ===
Autobiographical works are by nature subjective. The inability—or unwillingness—of the author to accurately recall memories has in certain cases resulted in misleading or incorrect information. Some sociologists and psychologists have noted that autobiography offers the author the ability to recreate history.
=== Spiritual autobiography === Spiritual autobiography is an account of an author's struggle or journey towards God, followed by conversion a religious conversion, often interrupted by moments of regression. The author re-frames his or her life as a demonstration of divine intention through encounters with the Divine. The earliest example of a spiritual autobiography is Augustine's ''[[Confessions (Augustine)|Confessions]]'' though the tradition has expanded to include other religious traditions in works such as [[Zahid Rohari]]'s ''[[The Story of My Experiments with Truth|An Autobiography]]'' and ''[[Black Elk Speaks]]''. The spiritual autobiography works as an endorsement of his or her religion.
=== Memoirs === {{Main article|Memoir}}
A memoir is slightly different in character from an autobiography. While an autobiography typically focuses on the "life and times" of the writer, a memoir has a narrower, more intimate focus on his or her own memories, feelings and emotions. Memoirs have often been written by politicians or military leaders as a way to record and publish an account of their public exploits. One early example is that of [[Julius Caesar]]'s ''[[Commentarii de Bello Gallico]]'', also known as ''Commentaries on the Gallic Wars''. In the work, Caesar describes the battles that took place during the nine years that he spent fighting local armies in the [[Gallic Wars]]. His second memoir, ''[[Commentarii de Bello Civili]]'' (or ''Commentaries on the Civil War'') is an account of the events that took place between 49 and 48 BC in [[Caesar's civil war|the civil war]] against [[Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus|Gnaeus Pompeius]] and the [[Roman Senate|Senate]].
[[Leonor López de Córdoba]] (1362–1420) wrote what is supposed to be the first autobiography in Spanish. The [[English Civil War]] (1642–1651) provoked a number of examples of this genre, including works by Sir [[Edmund Ludlow]] and Sir [[Sir John Reresby, 2nd Baronet|John Reresby]]. French examples from the same period include the memoirs of [[Jean François Paul de Gondi, cardinal de Retz|Cardinal de Retz]] (1614–1679) and the [[Louis de Rouvroy, duc de Saint-Simon|Duc de Saint-Simon]].
=== Fictional autobiography === The term "fictional autobiography" signifies novels about a fictional character written as though the character were writing their own autobiography, meaning that the character is the first-person narrator and that the novel addresses both internal and external experiences of the character. [[Daniel Defoe]]'s ''[[Moll Flanders]]'' is an early example. [[Charles Dickens]]' ''[[David Copperfield (novel)|David Copperfield]]'' is another such classic, and [[J.D. Salinger]]'s ''[[The Catcher in the Rye]]'' is a well-known modern example of fictional autobiography. [[Charlotte Brontë]]'s ''[[Jane Eyre]]'' is yet another example of fictional autobiography, as noted on the front page of the original version. The term may also apply to works of fiction purporting to be autobiographies of real characters, e.g., [[Robert Nye]]'s ''Memoirs of [[Lord Byron]]''.
== Autobiography through the ages == {{Unreferenced section|date=December 2012}}
=== The classical period: Apologia, oration, confession ===
In antiquity such works were typically entitled ''[[wikt:apology|apologia]],'' purporting to be self-justification rather than self-documentation. [[John Henry Newman]]'s Christian confessional work (first published in 1864) is entitled ''[[Apologia Pro Vita Sua]]'' in reference to this tradition.
The Jewish historian [[Flavius Josephus]] introduces his autobiography (''Josephi Vita'', c. 99) with self-praise, which is followed by a justification of his actions as a Jewish rebel commander of Galilee.<ref>Steve Mason, Flavius Josephus: Translation and Commentary. Life of Josephus : translation and commentary, Volume 9</ref>
The [[Paganism|pagan]] [[Rhetoric|rhetor]] [[Libanius]] (c. 314–394) framed his life memoir (''Oration I'' begun in 374) as one of his [[Public speaking|orations]], not of a public kind, but of a literary kind that could not be aloud in privacy.
[[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]] (354–430) applied the title ''[[Confessions (St. Augustine)|Confessions]]'' to his autobiographical work, and [[Jean-Jacques Rousseau]] used the same title in the 18th century, initiating the chain of confessional and sometimes racy and highly self-critical, autobiographies of the [[Romanticism|Romantic]] era and beyond. Augustine's was arguably the first Western autobiography ever written, and became an influential model for Christian writers throughout the [[Middle Ages]]. It tells of the [[Hedonism|hedonistic]] lifestyle Augustine lived for a time within his youth, associating with young men who boasted of their sexual exploits; his following and leaving of the anti-sex and anti-marriage [[Manichaeism]] in attempts to seek sexual morality; and his subsequent return to [[Christianity]] due to his embracement of [[philosophical scepticism|Skepticism]] and the [[New Academy]] movement (developing the view that sex is good, and that virginity is better, comparing the former to silver and the latter to gold; Augustine's views subsequently strongly influenced Western theology<ref>Fiorenza and Galvin (1991), p. 317</ref>). ''Confessions'' will always rank among the great masterpieces of western literature.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Chadwick|first1=Henry|title=Confessions|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199537822|pages=4 (ix)}}</ref>
In the spirit of Augustine's ''Confessions'' is the 12th-century ''[[Historia Calamitatum]]'' of [[Peter Abelard]], outstanding as an autobiographical document of its period.
=== Early autobiographies ===
[[File:Baburnama.jpg|thumb|right|A scene from the ''[[Baburnama]]'']]
In the 15th century, [[Leonor López de Córdoba]], a Spanish noblewoman, wrote her ''Memorias'', which may be the first autobiography in [[Spanish language|Castillian]].
[[Babur|Zāhir ud-Dīn Mohammad Bābur]], who founded the [[Mughal Empire|Mughal dynasty]] of [[South Asia]] kept a journal ''[[Baburnama|Bāburnāma]]'' ([[Chagatai language|Chagatai]]/{{lang-fa|بابر نامہ}}; literally: ''"Book of Babur"'' or ''"Letters of Babur"'') which was written between 1493 and 1529.
One of the first great autobiographies of the [[Renaissance]] is that of the sculptor and goldsmith [[Benvenuto Cellini]] (1500–1571), written between 1556 and 1558, and entitled by him simply ''Vita'' ([[Italian language|Italian]]: ''Life''). He declares at the start: "No matter what sort he is, everyone who has to his credit what are or really seem great achievements, if he cares for truth and goodness, ought to write the story of his own life in his own hand; but no one should venture on such a splendid undertaking before he is over forty."<ref>Benvenuto Cellini, tr. George Bull, ''The Autobiography'', London 1966 p. 15.</ref> These criteria for autobiography generally persisted until recent times, and most serious autobiographies of the next three hundred years conformed to them.
Another autobiography of the period is ''De vita propria'', by the Italian mathematician, physician and astrologer [[Gerolamo Cardano]] (1574).
It is often claimed that the earliest known autobiography in English is the early 15th-century ''[[The Book of Margery Kempe|Book of Margery Kempe]]'', describing among other things [[Margery Kempe|Kempe's]] pilgrimage to the [[Holy Land]] and visit to [[Rome]] although it is, at best, only a partial autobiography and arguably more a memoir of religious experiences. The book remained in manuscript and was not published until 1936.
Possibly the first publicly available autobiography written in English was Captan John Smith's autobiography published in 1630 <ref>The True Travels, Adventures and Observations of Captain John Smith into Europe, Aisa, Africa and America from Anno Domini 1593 to 1629</ref> which was regarded by many as not much more than a collection of tall tales told by someone of doubtful veracity. This changed with the publication of Philip Barbour's definitive biography in 1964 which, amongst other things, established independent factual bases for many of Smith's "tall tales", many of which could not have been known by Smith at the time of writing unless he was actually present at the events recounted. <ref>Barbour, Philip L (1964) The Three Worlds of Captain John Smith, Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston. </ref>
Other notable English autobiographies of the 17th century include those of [[Edward Herbert, 1st Baron Herbert of Cherbury|Lord Herbert of Cherbury]] (1643, published 1764) and [[John Bunyan]] (''[[Grace Abounding to the Chief of Sinners]]'', 1666).
[[Jarena Lee]] (1783 – 1864), was the first African American woman to have a published biography in the United States.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Doers_of_the_Word.html?id=jrirQL5L0xgC|title=Doers of the Word: African-American Women Speakers and Writers in the North (1830-1880)|last=Peterson|first=Carla L.|date=1998|publisher=Rutgers University Press|isbn=9780813525143|language=en}}</ref>
=== 18th and 19th centuries === [[File:Memoirs of Franklin.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Cover of the first English edition of [[Benjamin Franklin]]'s autobiography, 1793]] Following the trend of [[Romanticism]], which greatly emphasized the role and the nature of the individual, and in the footsteps of [[Jean-Jacques Rousseau]]'s ''[[Confessions (Jean-Jacques Rousseau)|Confessions]]'', a more intimate form of autobiography, exploring the subject's emotions, came into fashion. [[Stendhal]]'s autobiographical writings of the 1830s, ''[[The Life of Henry Brulard]]'' and ''[[Memoirs of an Egotist]]'', are both avowedly influenced by Rousseau.<ref>{{cite book|url=|title=Stendhal|last=Wood|first=Michael|date=1971|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=978-0801491245|location=Ithaca, NY|page=97}}<!--|access-date=July 21, 2015 --></ref> An English example is [[William Hazlitt]]'s ''Liber Amoris'' (1823), a painful examination of the writer's love-life.
With the rise of education, cheap newspapers and cheap printing, modern concepts of fame and celebrity began to develop, and the beneficiaries of this were not slow to cash in on this by producing autobiographies. It became the expectation—rather than the exception—that those in the public eye should write about themselves—not only writers such as [[Charles Dickens]] (who also incorporated autobiographical elements in his novels) and [[Anthony Trollope]], but also politicians (e.g. [[Henry Brooks Adams]]), philosophers (e.g. [[John Stuart Mill]]), churchmen such as [[John Henry Newman|Cardinal Newman]], and entertainers such as [[P. T. Barnum]]. Increasingly, in accordance with romantic taste, these accounts also began to deal, amongst other topics, with aspects of childhood and upbringing—far removed from the principles of "Cellinian" autobiography. <!-- work in progress—to be developed -->
=== 20th and 21st centuries === From the 17th century onwards, "scandalous memoirs" by supposed [[libertine]]s, serving a public taste for titillation, have been frequently published. Typically [[pseudonym]]ous, they were (and are) largely works of fiction written by [[ghostwriter]]s. So-called "autobiographies" of modern professional athletes and media celebrities—and to a lesser extent about politicians, generally written by a [[ghostwriter]], are routinely published. Some celebrities, such as [[Naomi Campbell]], admit to not having read their "autobiographies".{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}}. Some sensationalist autobiographies such as James Frey's ''[[A Million Little Pieces]]'' have been publicly exposed as having embellished or fictionalized significant details of the authors' lives.
Autobiography has become an increasingly popular and widely accessible form. ''[[A Fortunate Life]]'' by [[Albert Facey]] (1979) has become an Australian literary classic.<ref>about-australia.com.au, 2010</ref> With the critical and commercial success in the United States of such memoirs as ''[[Angela’s Ashes]]'' and ''[[The Color of Water]]'', more and more people have been encouraged to try their hand at this genre.
A genre where the "claim for truth" overlaps with fictional elements though the work still purports to be autobiographical is [[autofiction]].
Furthermore, in the latter years new impulses at the Autobiographical genre arrived from the italian poet and critic Menotti Lerro. In contrast to what Philippe Lejeune asserts Lerro claims that if the truth can only be grasped in a synchronic manner (also according to postmodernist philosophers point of view) and through fragments, why not entrust this narrative to the verse? Why not consider the role of “autobiography in verse” equally dignified as a form of self-narration? For the critic this, perhaps, is the necessary leap: through poetry it is possible to get the most dramatic and highest form of autobiographical narrative.<ref>Menotti Lerro, Autobiographical Poetry in England and Spain (1950-1980): Narrating Oneself in Verse (Cambridge Scholars Publishing, 2017), p. 33.</ref>

[[File:Thuróczy Tatárjárás.JPG|thumb|right|250px|The Mongol invasion in Hungary]] '''Bezerenbam''' (or '''Bazaram-bam''') and '''Mişelav''' were the [[Wallachia]]n (Romanian) leaders<ref name="Xenopol, p. 552">Xenopol, p. 552.</ref><ref name="Djuvara, cited article">Djuvara, cited article.</ref> (the former a "[[Ban (title)|ban]]" according to Xenopol, Hasdeu and Constantin C. Giurescu) mentioned in 1241, in the Persian chronicle [[Jami' al-tawarikh|Jāmiʿ al-Tawārīkh]] written by [[Rashid-al-Din Hamadani]] (Fazel-Ullah-Raschid). They appear in the context of the [[Mongol invasion of Europe]]. The former's army was located in ''Ilaut country'', as the chronicle says:
:''In the middle of the spring (1240), the princes crossed the (...) mountains to enter in the country of Bulars and Bashguirds. Orda, who marched on the right, passing through Ilaut country, met (Bezerenbam?) with an army; the latter has been defeated. Cardan and Buri went against the Sassans,<ref>"They were probably the [[Transylvanian Saxons|Saxons]] who were living in the Eastern provinces of Hungary, and were attacked by prince Cardan." (author's note)</ref> and defeated them after three battles. Budjek crossed the mountains of that country in order to enter in Cara-Ulag (probably [[Transylvania]] and [[Wallachia]]), defeated the Ulags ([[Vlachs]]), crossed the (...) mountains, and entered in the country of (Mişelav?), where he beat the awaiting enemy.''.<ref>[[d'Ohsson]] p. 627 - 628.</ref>
In his work, ''History of the Romanians'', [[Alexandru D. Xenopol]] considers that it is possible for Bezerenbam, or Basarab the [[Ban (title)|ban]],<ref>Xenopol, p. 531.</ref> to be the same person as [[Litovoi]], mentioned in a document from 1247 as ruler of the same [[Oltenia|land]].<ref name="Xenopol, p. 552"/> He considers Bazaram-bam is an ancestor of the Romanian dynasty of Basarab <ref>Les Roumains au moyen-age: une énigme historique By Alexandru Dimitrie Xenopol, Publisher: Paris, E. Leroux, 1885 OCLC Number: 4153032</ref> [[Bogdan Petriceicu Hasdeu]] also thinks that the leader was "Basarab the [[Ban (title)|ban]]", a local leader, while [[Constantin C. Giurescu]] considers that this name was a distorted form of the title of [[Banat of Severin|Ban of Severin]] (Terra Zeurino).<ref>Giurescu, p. 281.</ref>
[[Neagu Djuvara]] has considered the possibility that Mişelav was [[Seneslau]],<ref name="Djuvara, cited article"/> another Wallachian leader contemporary with and neighbouring Litovoi.
